title: Newcastle Disease Virus (PDQ®)
description: Newcastle disease virus (NDV)- based therapy has been reported to be of benefit in clinical studies, but results are considered inconclusive. Study designs were weak and the study reports were generally incomplete. Get detailed information about NDV use in cancer in this summary for clinicians.
cleaned_text: Newcastle Disease Virus (PDQ®)-Health Professional Version Overview NOTE: The information in this summary is no longer being updated and is provided for reference purposes only. This [cancer](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45333&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) information summary provides an overview of the use of [Newcastle disease virus](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=446555&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) (NDV) as a treatment for people with cancer. The summary includes a brief history of NDV research, a review of [laboratory](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44512&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) and [animal studies](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=454774&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov), the of [clinical trials](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45961&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov), and possible [side effects](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46580&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) of NDV-based therapy. Several different strains of NDV will be discussed in the summary, including the Hungarian strain MTH (More Than Hope)-68. Information presented in some sections of the summary can also be found in tables located at the end of those sections. This summary contains the following key information: - NDV is usually thought to be an avian (i.e., bird) virus, but it also [infects](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45364&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov)humans. Although NDV causes a potentially fatal, noncancerous disease (Newcastle disease) in birds, it causes only minor illness in humans. - NDV appears to [replicate](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44621&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov)(i.e., reproduce) substantially better in human cancer [cells](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46476&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov)than it does in most normal human cells. - Individual strains of NDV are classified as [lytic](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44837&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov)or [nonlytic](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44838&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov). Viruses of both strain types can kill cancer cells, but lytic strains have the potential to do this more quickly because they damage the [plasma membrane](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44615&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov)of infected cells. Nonlytic strains appear to kill by interfering with cell [metabolism](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46173&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov). - Lytic strains of NDV have been studied in humans for their ability to kill cancer cells directly, but viruses of both strain types have been used to make [vaccines](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45938&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov)in an attempt to stimulate the [immune system](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46356&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov)to fight cancer. - NDV-based anticancer therapy has been reported to be of benefit in more than a dozen [clinical studies](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44195&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov), but the results of these studies must be considered inconclusive because the study designs were weak and the study reports were generally incomplete. Many of the medical and scientific terms used in the summary are hypertext linked (at first use in each section) to the [NCI Dictionary of Cancer Terms](https://www.cancer.gov/publications/dictionaries/cancer-terms/), which is oriented toward nonexperts. When a linked term is clicked, a definition will appear in a separate window. General Information Information presented in this section about the use of [Newcastle disease virus](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=446555&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) (NDV) in the treatment of human [cancer](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45333&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) is summarized in [Table 1](/about-cancer/treatment/cam/hp/ndv-pdq#_158) below. NDV is a [paramyxovirus](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44614&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) that causes Newcastle disease in a wide variety of birds (most notably, in chickens).[ [1](#cit/section_2.1)- [3](#cit/section_2.3)] This often fatal disease is characterized by [inflammation](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44042&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) of [respiratory tract](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44490&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) and of either [2](#cit/section_2.2), [4](#cit/section_2.4), [5](#cit/section_2.5)] NDV can also [infect](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45364&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) but, in humans, it is generally not very [virulent](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44842&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov), causing only mild flu-like symptoms or [conjunctivitis](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44197&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) and/or [6](#cit/section_2.6)- [14](#cit/section_2.14)] The perception that NDV can [replicate](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44621&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) up to 10,000 times better in human cancer [cells](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46476&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) than in most normal human cells [ [2](#cit/section_2.2), [6](#cit/section_2.6)- [10](#cit/section_2.10), [12](#cit/section_2.12), [13](#cit/section_2.13), [15](#cit/section_2.15)- [23](#cit/section_2.23)] has prompted in this virus as a potential anticancer agent. This phenomenon is apparently caused by defects in intracellular antiviral defenses of some cancer cells.[ [24](#cit/section_2.24)- [26](#cit/section_2.26)] NDV was historically considered a complementary and alternative medicine approach, but in recent years it has been extensively studied by the conventional medical community. Also, genetically engineered NDV strains are being developed and studied for their anticancer activity.[ [27](#cit/section_2.27)] The [genetic](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46391&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) viruses, essentially all of NDV's [replication cycle](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44624&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) takes place inside infected cells, which known as [host cells](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44597&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov).[ [13](#cit/section_2.13), [18](#cit/section_2.18), [30](#cit/section_2.30), [32](#cit/section_2.32)] During a replication cycle, new virus [proteins](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46092&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) and copies of the NDV genetic material (i.e., [genome](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44593&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov)) are made in the host cell's [cytoplasm](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44586&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov). NDV is also an [enveloped virus](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44588&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov), which means that [progeny](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44616&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) virus particles are released from infected cells by budding off from them.[ [18](#cit/section_2.18), [30](#cit/section_2.30), [33](#cit/section_2.33)] In this process, single copies of the NDV genome become wrapped in an outer coat (i.e., an envelope) that is made from a small piece of the host cell's [plasma membrane](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44615&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov). Generally, the NDV outer coat contains only virus proteins that have been specifically inserted into the host cell's plasma membrane;[ [18](#cit/section_2.18), [28](#cit/section_2.28), [32](#cit/section_2.32), [33](#cit/section_2.33)] however, some proteins may be included as well.[ [34](#cit/section_2.34), [35](#cit/section_2.35)] Two specific virus proteins, [hemagglutinin-neuraminidase](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44595&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) and the [fusion protein](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44591&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov), are the main NDV proteins found in the outer coat of isolated virus particles.[ [3](#cit/section_2.3), [18](#cit/section_2.18), [28](#cit/section_2.28), [30](#cit/section_2.30)] There are many different strains of NDV, and they have been classified as either [lytic](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44837&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) or [nonlytic](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44838&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) for human cells. Lytic strains and nonlytic strains both appear to replicate much more efficiently in human cancer cells than they do in most normal human cells,[ [12](#cit/section_2.12), [13](#cit/section_2.13), [15](#cit/section_2.15)- [20](#cit/section_2.20), [36](#cit/section_2.36)] and viruses of both strain types have been investigated as potential anticancer agents. One major difference between lytic strains and nonlytic strains is that lytic strains are able to make infectious progeny virus particles in human cells, whereas nonlytic strains are not.[ [13](#cit/section_2.13), [18](#cit/section_2.18), [28](#cit/section_2.28)- [30](#cit/section_2.30), [37](#cit/section_2.37)] This difference is due to the ability of lytic strains to produce activated hemagglutinin-neuraminidase and fusion protein [molecules](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45065&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) in the outer coat of progeny viruses in human cells. The progeny virus particles made by nonlytic strains contain inactive versions of these molecules. Activated hemagglutinin-neuraminidase and fusion protein molecules are required for NDV to enter a cell to replicate. Initial binding of NDV to a host cell takes place through the interaction of hemagglutinin-neuraminidase molecules in the virus coat with [sialic-acid](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44623&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov)-containing molecules (i.e., [gangliosides](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44592&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov)) on the surface of the cell. It is important to note, however, that nonlytic strains of NDV can make infectious progeny viruses in some types of nonhuman cells (e.g., chicken [embryo](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44202&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) cells), thereby allowing these strains to be maintained.[ [13](#cit/section_2.13), [18](#cit/section_2.18), [28](#cit/section_2.28), [29](#cit/section_2.29), [36](#cit/section_2.36)] Another major difference between lytic strains and nonlytic strains is that, although they both have the potential to kill infected cells, the mechanisms by which they accomplish this result are different. The production of infectious progeny virus particles by lytic strains gives them the ability to kill host cells fairly quickly. The budding of progeny viruses that contain activated hemagglutinin-neuraminidase and fusion protein molecules in their outer coats causes the plasma membrane of NDV-infected cells to fuse with the plasma membrane of adjacent cells, leading to the production of large, [inviable](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44604&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) fused cells known as [syncytia](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44625&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov).[ [12](#cit/section_2.12), [13](#cit/section_2.13), [18](#cit/section_2.18), [30](#cit/section_2.30)] The more efficiently a lytic strain can replicate inside a host cell, the more quickly it can kill that cell. The preferential killing of cancer cells by a lytic virus is known as [oncolysis](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44612&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov); thus, lytic strains of NDV are also called oncolytic strains. Nonlytic strains of NDV kill infected cells more slowly, with death apparently the result of [viral](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44629&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) disruption of normal host cell metabolism.[ [36](#cit/section_2.36), [38](#cit/section_2.38)] The specific mechanism by which nonlytic NDV strains cause cell death in cancer cells has not been completely elucidated, but in Vero cells (derived from kidney epithelium) it was determined that NDV caused cell death by decreasing DNA content, increasing the ratio of Bax to Bcl-2, increasing p53 level, and increasing caspase expression, resulting in apoptosis.[ [39](#cit/section_2.39)- [41](#cit/section_2.41)] As indicated previously, both lytic strains and nonlytic strains have been investigated for their anticancer potential. In fact, the major differences between the two strain types have been exploited to develop three different approaches to cancer therapy: - The infection of cancer patients with a lytic strain of NDV. - The use of [oncolysates](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44611&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov), i.e., preparations containing plasma membrane fragments from NDV-infected cancer calls, as anticancer [vaccines](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45938&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov). - The use of intact cancer cells infected with a nonlytic strain of NDV as [whole cell vaccines](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44923&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov). It is important to note that immune system responses similar to those obtained with oncolysates and whole cell vaccines may occur in patients infected with a lytic strain of NDV and that these [responses](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44085&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) would be expected to contribute to any observed anticancer effect. To conduct [human studies](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44195&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) with viruses, vaccines, or other [biological](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44510&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) materials in the United States, researchers must file an [Investigational](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44763&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) New Drug (IND) application with the [U.S. Food and Drug Administration](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=454785&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) (FDA). Biological materials and drugs have been held to similar safety and effectiveness standards since 1972. In an IND application, researchers must provide safety and [toxicity](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=43986&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) data from [laboratory](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44512&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) and [animal studies](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=454774&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) to justify the [dose](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44664&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov), the route, and the schedule of administration to be used in the proposed clinical studies. Among the safety issues to be addressed, researchers must demonstrate an absence of harmful contaminants. Most human studies of NDV as an anticancer agent have taken place outside the United States; therefore, they have not required an IND. At present, at least one group of U.S. [investigators](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44685&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) has filed an IND application to study NDV as an anticancer treatment.[ [59](#cit/section_2.59)] It should be noted that the FDA has not approved the use of NDV to treat any medical condition. In this regard, it is noteworthy that a larger percentage of patients in the NDV treatment group than in the placebo group received conventional therapy within the 3 months preceding the initiation of NDV therapy (82% vs. 58%).[ [39](#cit/section_5.39)] In fact, the average time between the completion of conventional therapy and the start of NDV therapy among the patients who had a either a complete response or a partial response was 1.8 months.[ [39](#cit/section_5.39)] Therefore, the contribution of NDV therapy to the observed clinical outcomes is difficult to determine. In a phase I trial that was conducted in the United States, another lytic NDV strain, PV701, was tested in patients with various advanced cancers.[ [44](#cit/section_5.44)] In this trial, 79 patients whose tumors had not responded to conventional therapy were given intravenous injections of virus. Four different treatment regimens were evaluated as follows: - A single dose of NDV given once every 28 days (17 patients). - A single dose of NDV given 3 times during a 1-week period, repeated every 28 days (13 patients). - Three injections of NDV given during a 1-week period, with the first injection containing a lower dose of virus than the remaining 2, repeated every 28 days (37 patients). - Six injections of NDV given during a 2-week period, with the first injection containing a lower dose of virus than the remaining 5, repeated every 21 days (12 patients). The researchers found that the use of lower initial doses of virus allowed the administration of higher subsequent doses. A complete response was reported for one patient, and partial tumor regression was observed in eight patients. Thirteen patients had stable disease for periods of time that lasted from 4 months to more than 30 months. Five patients died during the trial: four due to progressive disease and one due, possibly, to a treatment-related complication (refer to the [Adverse Effects](/about-cancer/treatment/cam/hp/ndv-pdq#_116) section of this summary for more information). Several patients experienced significant adverse side effects from NDV treatment, including fever, fatigue, dehydration, low blood pressure, shortness of breath, and hypoxia. Some patients who experienced these adverse effects required hospitalization. The researchers who conducted this trial have indicated that additional clinical studies are under way. A major concern about the effectiveness of treating cancer patients by repeated administration of a lytic strain of NDV is the possibility that the immune system will produce virus-neutralizing antibodies. Virus-neutralizing antibodies would prevent NDV from reaching and infecting malignant cells, thereby blocking oncolysis. Impairment of NDV infection would also limit the ability of cytotoxic T cells that target virus antigens to kill virus-infected cancer cells. In addition, limiting the infection of cancer cells would lessen the likelihood that the immune system would become trained to better recognize tumor-specific antigens. The Hungarian investigators have shown that anti-NDV antibodies are produced in MTH-68-treated patients,[ [38](#cit/section_5.38)] but they apparently have not determined whether these antibodies are virus-neutralizing. However, the recent observation that [immune system tolerance](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44598&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) to viruses can be induced by repeated [oral](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44068&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) administration of virus proteins suggests that the concern about virus-neutralizing antibodies may not be entirely warranted.[ [68](#cit/section_5.68), [69](#cit/section_5.69)] It is conceivable that frequent inhalation (or injection) of NDV may lead to immune system tolerance of this virus. Most reported [clinical studies](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44195&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) have involved few patients, and [historical control subjects](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44596&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) rather than actual [control groups](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44149&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) have often been used for outcome comparisons. Poor descriptions of study design and incomplete reporting of clinical data have hindered evaluation of many of the reported findings. However, while most studies are small and lack adequate controls, the number of studies suggesting a potential clinical value warrants further attention. Separate [levels of evidence](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=446533&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) scores are assigned to qualifying human studies on the basis of statistical strength of the study design and [scientific](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44724&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) strength of the treatment outcomes (i.e., [endpoints](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=346519&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov)) measured. The resulting two scores are then combined to produce an overall score. For additional information about levels of evidence analysis, refer to [Levels of Evidence for Human Studies of Integrative, Alternative, and Complementary Therapies](/publications/pdq/levels-evidence/cam).
